newsitem.title: ITALY: Prodi mulling EMU appeal to Italians-report.
newsitem.headline: Prodi mulling EMU appeal to Italians-report.

text.p: Prime Minister Romano Prodi is considering whether to make a televised appeal to Italians to support the country's drive to join Europe's planned single currency, the news magazine Panorama reported on Thursday.
It quoted the centre-left leader as saying there was a lack of information on the issue and he was awaiting the right moment to make his pitch.
"I am thinking of a message to the country, on television," the magazine quoted Prodi as saying in an advance release of its interview.
"The message would explain the advantages of us joining the European single currency because there really is a lack of information on this, but I need to wait until the time is right."

Prodi has presented a stringent 1997 budget to parliament which aims to cut 62.5 trillion lire ($42 billion) from next year's deficit to help Italy meet the terms for founder membership of monetary union from 1999.
The package is heavy on increased revenues, including from a special one-off "Euro tax" and has raised protests from businessmen, ordinary Italians and the centre-right opposition.
It has also exposed strains among the parties which support Prodi's coalition government, including the hard left Communist Refoundation party.
